EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



ES - 1.0 | FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY



The owners, management, and employees of the Dixon Wholesale, part of Grow West (herein referred to as Dixon Wholesale or the Dixon Facility) at 7235 Tremont Road, Dixon, California 95620 are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia, aqua ammonia, or regulated pesticides. If an accidental release should occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. A detailed Consolidated Contingency Plan (CCP) has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.





ES - 2.0 | FACILITY INFORMATION



* The Facility is a retail agricultural facility whose primary activity is the storage and sale of fertilizers in addition to the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to agricultural operations in Northern California. Applicable NAICS codes for this facility include 42491 (Farm Supplies Merchant Wholesalers) and 325311 (Nitrogenous Fertilizer Manufacturing).



* Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is received, converted, stored, and distributed for direct application as crop production nutrients.

 

* Anhydrous ammonia is converted to aqua ammonia (ammonium hydroxide) and reacted with super phosphoric acid (SPA) to produce ammonium phosphate [10-34-0] fertilizer).



* Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored in either an 18,000-gallon storage tank (bullet) or a 30,050-gallon storage tank.



* The anhydrous ammonia storage vessels are filled to no more than 85% of shell volume. 



Vessel     Capacity          Maximum Volume     Amount of NH3

Bullet 2   30,050 gals       25,542 gals        131,286 lbs

Totals     48,050 gals       40,842 gals        209,928 lbs



The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled is 209,928 pounds.

ia is produced from anhydrous ammonia and stored in a 10,000-gallon storage tank and an 18,000-gallon storage tank. 



* The aqua ammonia storage vessels are filled to no more than 85% of shell volume.

The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia (19% solution) handled is 184,212 pounds. The maximum amount of ammonia in the aqua solution is 34,986 lbs.





ES - 3.0 | ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Facility has implemented the following prevention program elements.



Safety Information:  Dixon Wholesale ensures that information concerning covered processes and regulated substances are up-to-date and available for review by employees. The most recent review of safety information pertaining to the covered processes took place on February 1, 2019.



Hazard Review:  A hazard review of the ammonia processes is conducted every five years or as needed by changes in the processes. The most recent update of the hazard review for the anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia processes was conducted on November 20, 2018. There were no high risk hazards identified through the hazard review updates.



Operating Procedures:  Written standard operating procedures have been developed for the covered processes and are reviewed and revised as needed. The operating procedures were last revised on January 30, 2019.



Training:  The Dixon Wholesale Facility staff, as well as Grow West corporate staff, understands that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an e

conducted every three years. Records of the audits and follow-up documentation are maintained to indicate findings and resolution of findings. The most recent compliance audit was conducted on July 17, 2019.



Incident Investigation:  Although no incidents involving regulated substances have occurred at the Facility in the last five years, an incident investigation program is in place. The program includes investigation requirements and reporting and would be implemented in the event of an incident.



Employee Participation:  The Facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations. The Dixon Facility has an Employee Participation Program in place and has implemented procedures regarding engaging employees for their input, as well as ensuring access to safety documentation to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program.



Hot Work Permit:  With regard to hot work that may occur on or near the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, Dixon Wholesale has developed a written Hot Work Permit to document the evaluation of the fire prevention and protection requirements.



Contractor Safety:  The contractors used by the Facility for anhydrous ammonia delivery have been informed regarding the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to delivery of anhydrous ammonia to the Dixon Wholesale Facility. The Facility has confirmed that the delivery contractors have provided the appropriate training to their drivers regarding the delivery of anhydrous ammonia. Dixon Wholesale also qualifies contractors who are engaged in maintaining the RS systems to ensure that equipment is modified or repaired, and returned to service safely.

ES - 4.0 | FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia, aqua ammonia, or regulated pesticides during the last five years resulting in death, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, or property or environmental damage.





ES - 5.0 | THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility's emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan requirements. The Consolidated Contingency Plan (CCP) was most recently updated on September 25, 2018 and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.





ES - 6.0 | PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Safety improvement is an on-going process at the Facility. Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Specific changes to the anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia processes at the Facility will be implemented as needed.





ES - 7.0 | THE WORST-CASE R

ELEASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS



Anhydrous Ammonia Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios. The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 131,288 pounds of anhydrous ammonia; this represents the volume of the larger storage tank administratively limited at 85% of capacity. The alternative release scenario, based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident), is a release from a broken 2-inch diameter pipe with an increased wind speed and "D" stability modeling parameters.



Aqua Ammonia Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios. The worst-case scenario is failure of the largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 131,670 pounds of aqua ammonia that forms a liquid pool. The alternative release scenario, based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident), is a release from a pipe break modeled with an increased wind speed and "D" Stability modeling parameters.
